answers.author: Robert Whitaker
answers.text:
There are a number of options, if you have a labor contract or employment agreement type document I would check to see if that requires overtime be paid for this since it is hours in addition to his/her normally scheduled hours. Your other option would be to check with a labor attorney to see if there is a FLSA Exemption for this type of position if his/her duties are completely different than those that he/she does during his/her normally scheduled shifts.

author: Cody Rose
text:
I work for a Fire District. I know this may be somewhat different than the municipality, but overall subject may be similar. We are proposing to have our labor representative work in administration two days a week. We currently are calling the position Quality Control Officer. I am looking for some info on job description, how to pay him (overtime, salary from new position, or flat hourly rate that he currently makes now when working at the fire station). If you have any other ideas of how to make this work it would be much appreciated.
Thanks,
Cody
